title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Zimbabwe engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Zimbabwe?
preds:
Although there have been a number of protests that have ended in violence in Zimbabwe, the probability of 1,000 or more civilians being killed is unlikely. Recent price hikes on essentials, such as fuel has led to a series of protests against the government. Government crackdowns on the protests have turned to violence but no systematic killings have been enacted. Although, the crackdowns have resulted in deaths there is no evidence of systematic killings of civilians in mass taking place. 
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/security-forces-in-zimbabwe-kill-12-protesters-in-broadest-crackdown-on-unrest-in-years/2019/01/21/ceafcef6-1cf0-11e9-a759-2b8541bbbe20_story.html?utm_term=.61bad6f44990

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 5.0%. [1] 
- Crowd forecast here is 0%. Inside view:
- there do seem to be recent incidents of violence [2] [3] [4]. However, at most 20 people seem to have been killed. There was some more violence in April,  but nobody was killed [5] 
- political violence seems to be most likely, but it's not clear to me how it would escalate into a mass killing campaign.  Overal judgment: 
- base rate of 2% seems about right. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/zimbabwe
[2] https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/01/zimbabwe-violent-crackdown-continues-reports-rape-190125184915333.html
[3] https://edition.cnn.com/2019/01/19/africa/zimbabwe-violence-protesters/index.html
[4] https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2019/01/24/zimbabwe-sees-its-worst-state-violence-in-a-decade
[5] https://allafrica.com/stories/201904020117.html
